posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
for each streamer you want to do this for:

yt-dlp --live-from-start --wait-for-video 60 <stream URL>


--live-from-start begins downloading from the beginning of the stream, not current time. --wait-for-video 60 will re-check if the stream is live every minute and begin recording when it goes live.

a more resource-friendly way would be to run a script which indefinitely loops through a list of target streamers every minute and runs the yt-dlp command for each streamer ASYNCHRONOUSLY without --wait-for-video. without this flag, if yt-dlp errors out and quits, this means the stream isn't live, check next URL. if it does not error out, the stream is downloaded in a separate non-blocking process

yt-dlp still struggles with chunks, ads, and waiting to download live chunks after downloading the entire broadcast. if it doesn't work for you try streamlink

posts.com:
>>1317234
I'm still a beginner but going from I don't know what I'm doing to top 3 and winning races against the AI in the Brands Hatch circuit feels good.

- Boonatix has "A real begginer guide to sim racing" on Youtube. That helped me a lot.
- Dirt Rally 1 has some tutorials on rally driving which explain a ton of the car physics, you can watch them online on Youtube.
- Kame Trick (also a youtuber) has content on drifting if that's something you want to look into in the future.
- For learning actual normie driving you can try City car driving (Steam store)

You can look for tips on specific circuits you're trying to learn. For example you sometimes have real drivers explaining real circuits in your game, like https://youtu.be/tioNaoSiWIo
That video was what made me actually win my first race in that circuit.
Remember that real drivers usually drive slower than e-sports pros because they're used to the real thing and they are prone to lack feedback from the sim racing rig because of the same. They drive actual cars.

I also feel like the progression of Assetto Corsa (not Competizione) is better since you start with slower cars, which is usually the best for when you're learning. You have to be willing to put up with the shitty UI (get Content Manager if on PC) or play the PS4 version that has a not shit UI.

Good Evening /wsr/

An important, unsolved problem in Computational Maidposting is the problem of finding the smallest anime maid.

I am looking for a pixel artist who can help draw a very small anime maid. The maid must have a minimal amount of colors (2 works best).

I will use Maid Space to count to the Maid you provide and put it in a CC0 book.

Small images can make really crazy big numbers. For example in a 10 by 10 Maid Space with radix 2 (only 2 colors in the drawing), that can count to 2^(100)-1 which is a number that is way too big to put in a book. Add a third color and it becomes 3^(100)-1 possible images.

Please draw the smallest possible anime maid with the smallest possible number of colors so I can count to the maid.

Thank you /wsr/ for reading my post.

Counting looks like the attached image, except dimensions are whatever height and width the image you make is and radix is the number of colors used. Then the maid can get counted.

Books will help other people see how Maid Space works and then when the Maid Phone comes and the software releases maids can use the books to see what the math their computer is doing is for and how it works. Both the file system and the networked communications will make heavy use of Maid Space.

>>1317221
Thank you for trying my question. The goal is as few pixels and colors as possible. The reason is because of how fast Maid Space numbers get bigger. If you draw a maid, the Maid Address for her is somewhere between zero and the number of colors you used raised to a power equal to the number of pixels in the image, minus one. So counting can take a long time and make a huge book, or be beyond practical limitations of the computer.

Imagine you need four colors and drew the maid in a eight by six image. A radix four, eight by six Maid Space counts from zero to seventy-nine octillion two hundred twenty-eight septillion one hundred sixty-two sextillion five hundred fourteen quintillion two hundred sixty-four quadrillion three hundred thirty seven trillion five hundred ninety-three billion five hundred fourty-three million nine hundred fifty thousand three hundred thirty four.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

>>1316747
Compassion meditation. The Center for Healthy Minds has a few free mp3s. The half hour one narrated by Helen Weng, who is a researcher but she could do voiceover work, is well researched and shows positive effects.

It's not "om" or watch your breath and certainly not "clear your mind". It's little bits of "may I be well and happy, may my loved one be well and happy, may this stranger be well and happy, may this person I find difficult be well and happy". There are others too like watching the breath or things like that, but this is my preferred one. It's really easy, the hardest part is sitting down to do it. I found it was positive, I heartily encourage you to look it up.

Just looked it up myself. Looks like they've gone app for Android and ios. You can sign up on the website to download the mp3s. https://centerhealthyminds.org/join-the-movement/compassion-training

Instead of posting on the internet, go out and volunteer somewhere. I'd say not just shovelling your neighbour's sidewalk which is a really nice thing to do, but something regular and routine every week away from your house. Since you're already wasting time you're not going to lose anything worth having except maybe a couple of bucks for transport. You might be around some like minded people who want to do good and do it well. You'll also be with real people and that's much better than the anonymising effect of Internet interaction. Instead of hiding behind your anonymity you'll have to deal with people more appropriately and there are people who will punch you in the face if you get too fresh with them which is good incentive, even if you do go to the gym. If you can find time for that, you can find time to refine your mind and attitude as well.

Just go out and help someone.

General interest link https://centerhealthyminds.org/join-the-movement/9-ways-to-stop-being-negative which might help.

App links at bottom https://hminnovations.org/well-being-tools

May you be well and happy.

So hear me out: Read the Manga, Google Search scenes that you like and see how the look animated. If you're curious about non Canon/Filler episodes, watch random ones. Filler is cute sometimes, unnecessary most though. And if you're really curious, watch some of the movies. But with time management, the manga is faster. I went from Volume 85(Chapter 849 - 858) to 98(Chapter 985-994) in 6 months. Yes I took breaks, I'm a college student and serve/work for a handful of places. but there was a period in those months where I was speed reading multiple volumes for a few weeks. You could go through 10 chapters in 40 minutes if you actually concentrate and embrace the story. Sorry for anyone who's low attention spanned or aDD/aDHD

Also, if you choose to read the manga, please read the recent color version releases. After 2005, the art style becomes looser and messier making sequences harder to process. I read the Viz Media translations cuz that's what I'm used to from childhood, but they don't have the color versions. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1317047
>muh...Then is a patch of a patch?
No, it's replacing PA the same way PA replaced "locked exclusive access to the soundcard"
>It looks like a way to force wayland.
I don't see anything that ties it to wayland, other than your client applications maybe not supporting it?
>Can it be enabled alsa only?
From what I see, it has alsa input and output adapters, so I don't see why not. It also seems to have pulseaudio input.

It's important to understand that alsa isn't a program, it's a library that things that want to output audio load and then run as part of themselves. Alsa.conf tells the library that's built into each process how to configure itself, but (unlike pulseaudio and pipewire) there's no "alsa" process and alsa isn't running. So anything that's loaded an "alsa library" that's actually a wrapper around pulseaudio or pipewire will end up talking to pulseaudio or pipewire

posts.com:
>>1317094
Pipewire isn't only for audio, it's for all things multimedia. It's an interface for audio, screen recording, webcam, etc.
If you only use pipewire for audio then it can still be beneficial, but more-so if you are streaming and doing things like that because you can use things like this with pipewire: https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/rncbc/qpwgraph where you can redirect audio from programs to one audio input, at runtime. It's nice for more professional use, the average person wont benefit from this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1317322
>the average person wont benefit from this.
And yet they're ripping out pulseaudio anyway, so as not to have to maintain two parallel subsystems that do the same thing.

From what I can tell, the main complaint is that pipewire can't synchronise over network links (and doesn't really have good or even existing support for chromecast, airplay, miracast, upnp, etc.), and the same things that make it good for low-latency on your local machine (chiefly no buffer invalidation) make this an unsolvable problem when you're not on 10G-with-no-packet-loss-ever.

But anyways, too bad. Pulseaudio is being taken out the back and shot, because who wants to maintain two OSes worth of audio simultaneously?

posts.com: Anyone know of any good walking trails in County Durham and North Yorkshire? I live in the Tees valley and want to go on a walk with my dad but I don't know of any good ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Are the Yorkshire Dales in your travel range? They're quite beautfiul, and if you're near Bolton Abbey you can see the Strid, a section of the Wharfe that flows downward.

If you follow the Tees upstream up past Barnard Castle it goes along somevery nice parts of the Pennines. Lot of walks around those parts, with parking near views like Cauldron Snout.

Lastly, by the sea near Peterlee and Hartlepool there's also some nice cliff-side walks like Blackhall Rocks, where you can follow the coast for a bit.

The OSMaps website also often includes a lot of recommended trail maps if you're curious about anything that might be more within walking distance of wherever you might live, and you can filter them by estimated length and walk time.
https://explore.osmaps.com

posts.com: What's the best extension/website/whatever to download audio from Youtube videos in the year 2023? There's a ton of random options around, but I'm wondering which one(s) would yield the best quality results without too much hindrance?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316934
You should be using Soulseek for music slsknet.org
Otherwise yt-dlp is worth learning how to use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
yt-dlp
you just type

yt-dlp YOUTUBELINKGOESHERE -F

then you get a list of available streams, you will want the highest quality .webm audio (opus) or .m4a audio, the number for these is usually 251 and 140 respectively

so then you do

yt-dlp YOUTUBELINKGOESHERE -f 251
or
yt-dlp YOUTUBELINKGOESHERE -f 140
then it should appear in whatever directory your terminal is open at, and if it isn't open anywhere it defaults to your home folder

Note: uppercase -F is for fetching the list of available streams, lowercase -f is used to download the desired format(s)

Gook/Goot/Gookmoot was Ayamari's original name, her original intention was to replace Hiroshimoot as a mascot of 4chan after hearing comments about redesigning Hiro.

When anons told me the reality story about Hiro, she was "made all for nothing" and I loved her too much to throw all the ideas and effort away, so I asked what to do with her. Her name changed to Ayamari which translate to あやまり [By the time of 2020, it meant Error or Mistake. Right now, it means "Sorry" on Google Translate for some reason.]
She was like a nomad/journeyman roaming around on 4chan until she came across /v/orld 3, which I took a chance.
>>>/v/554011443 Considering it's 4chan, one story say had she never said "nigger", she'd never be allowed in the thread. A PC is the best option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1317093
this is kind of a tricky question since a lot of it comes down to what you want out of it

if you just want to play some games, i think the most economical deal right now is an xbox series s and xbox game pass. the console's cheap and the game pass subscription gives you access to a LOT of games, many of them are even good.

if you just don't want to *build* a pc, you can get one from any number of system integrators. you can see a list of popular ones here: https://techguided.com/best-custom-pc-builders/

keep in mind you'll be paying at minimum an extra $100-200 over self-assembly doing it this way, potentially even a lot more, and the question of "how much should i spend" comes down to a combination of "what do i want to play" and "what level of graphical detail is adequate for me." first midrange one i found that looks adequate for a middle-of-the-road build is this: https://www.ibuypower.com/store/gaming-rdy-slhbg216

i would say this is less bang-for-buck than a series s and gamepass

note you can build a computer for MUCH cheaper than this, but if you're not comfortable doing that, i won't recommend it, there ARE things you can fuck up. i built my own pc for about $600 using a combination of new parts and stuff from ebay, but i also work in IT professionally so i have a lot of experience with this that you won't have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1317115
used PCs are also a viable option, you can often pick them up for much cheaper, just be wary of deals that seem too good to be true. ironically despite the FUD about them, old mining rigs can make for decent midrange gaming PCs as long as they were well-maintained. and older business computers are often only a couple hundred on system reseller websites; you won't be playing a lot of modern stuff on those, they're generally very low end, but you'll still have access to a huge library of games even on a budget pc.
